name: Þingeyri
description: Þingeyri is a historic fishing village and the largest settlement in the Dýrafjörður fjord of the Westfjords, with a population of approximately 260 residents. Founded as a trading post in the 16th century, Þingeyri is one of Iceland's oldest continuously inhabited communities and served as a major commercial center during the golden age of Westfjords herring fishing. The town's name derives from 'Þing,' meaning parliament or assembly, as it was historically a meeting place for regional governance. Today, Þingeyri offers authentic small-town Icelandic life with colorful traditional houses, a picturesque harbor, and dramatic mountain backdrops including the distinctive flat-topped mountain Sandafell. The town features one of Iceland's oldest general stores, Símb ærinn, which has operated continuously since 1915 and now serves as both a shop and local museum showcasing early 20th-century commerce. Þingeyri is a popular base for exploring the remote Westfjords, offering essential services including grocery stores, a swimming pool, accommodation, and one of the region's few year-round restaurants. The town hosts an annual music festival celebrating traditional Icelandic folk music. Nearby attractions include scenic hiking trails, abandoned farms in side valleys, and some of Iceland's least-visited but most spectacular fjords.

opening_hours.services: Grocery store, swimming pool, accommodation, restaurant
